title: Is it too late to become a musician for me if I’m 21 and just started learning the guitar last year? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, it is absolutely NOT too late for you to become a respectable guitarist. Let me explain with a few points-some personal and some not. 1. I taught myself to play flamenco and folk guitar when I was 11. By the time I was 13, I had attained a certain level of proficiency which (at the tender age of 13) made me feel like it would be possible to continue, but not without some type of formal instruction. My father promised me that he would try to enroll me into classes with Sophocles Pappas in DC (at that time). For a number of reasons, this did not occur. But it did not stop me. I spent the years from age 11 (grade school) through high school (grade 12). I also felt like I had made no progress. My brother and I used to play and sing at a place called “Through the Gate” cofee house on Capitol Hill in DC. The repertoire consisted on the same songs, played the same way, for 3 years until my brother died in an accident. Still, no advancement and no progress. I went through the motions of playing after my brother died. I covered everything I had played up to that point. I worked on fingerstyle, I worked on flamenco with golpe, I worked on everything that I knew. At that point, I realized that what I needed to know in order to succeed was not something I could watch other people doing. I had to learn how to do what they did (whatever it was!) through formal instruction. When I was your age, I had already sold all of my guitars and had spent my first year in the Army. I had never stopped my love affair with the guitar, but money for lessons continued to be a HUGE problem. It scarred my soul to sell my guitars. Fast forward a couple of years. I played percussions in a band, wind instruments like sax and flute with the Montgomery County Chamber Music Society, and even played one of Orsino's musicians (flutist, stage name Marie-Therese Lintz) with the Shakespeare Theater's 1989–1990 season production of The Twelfth Night in Washington, DC. It all left me cold. I had been playing guitar since I was a kid, and THAT'S what I wanted to do. Just that. Nothing else. In summary, you are ABSOLUTELY NOT TOO YOUNG to learn to play the guitar. But you must understand that playing the guiitar, as with any other instrument, takes many, many hours of work. It does not matter what style you want to play. It ALL takes a tremendous amount of work. If you are serious about the instrument, do not be surprised that you may lose friends who do not understand how much mastering the instrument—and how much it will take to do so. It doesn't really matter what style you want to play. I want to master Bach, Albeniz, Rodrigo and other Spanich composers. You may want to play head over heels better than Malmsteeen or Vai. In any case, or for any genre, you need to understand that you have hit plateaus, and you need to KEEP ON KEEPIN'’ ON, even though you may think that you are getting nowhere. JUST KEEP DOING IT. Lastly, add a few bucks to your monthly budget and find yourself a good TEACHER. A good teacher does not equal a good guitarist. A musician who loves to teach is a good teacher. That is the most important thing you can spend your money on. Don't make the mistake of thinking that because someone is a great player, that makes him/her a great teacher. Nothing could be further than the truth. This is a serious search you have to make. Find someone who loves to teach. My own PHENOMENAL teacher is a guy who studied (and made high honors in) classicial guitar. His love of guitar? METAL. Good luck to you. Don't give up. It's too soon for you to do that. Look for a teacher—preferably one who has studied guitar performamce at a University—who loves to teach. You will not be sorry!

Absolutely not. You’re never to old to start ANYTHING. I’m 30 and I’m just now starting to do things I wish I would have started when I was 21. Do I wish I had that extra 9 years of experience? Of course. But what if I say, “I’m 30, that’s too old to start!” and then I turn 40, still have the desire to do it and start then? That’s another 10 years of experience I could have had, that I wasted wondering if I was too old to do it. That’s how people end up on their deathbeds wondering what could have been if they would have just went for it. “I just care if I can be able to make my own music. Genre I love to most is electronic rock, this is the kind of music I would love to make.” You need nothing else. Were you born with a guitar in your hand? No? Me neither. Neither was anybody else. The reason we have good musicians is because, just like you, they just wanted to make music, so they decided to. Forget all of the ideas of “they had talent!” “They have a gift for it!” “They’re a natural!” Those are all excuses people make for not doing something they want to do. “I can’t do what they do because I don’t have the gift like them.” Well then you can continue buying albums instead of making them, and being a consumer instead of a creator. The reason we have great guitar players like Hendrix in our history isn’t do to “talent” and “gifts,” as blasphemous as that is to say in the guitar community. It’s do to them bringing a unique perspective to the instrument and the music. They still had to put in hours of practice. They still messed up during live shows and recordings. They still had to wake up every day and decide, “I’m going to play guitar today.” Do you know who else has a unique perspective? You. You’ll have your own style, your own way of looking at the guitar, and your own sense of what sounds good that will become a common emphasis and trademark of your music. All you’re lacking right now is the confidence to fully dive in. But you have the desire, and that is all you need. You get the confidence by continuing to learn, because the more you see you’re capable, the more excited you’ll be to keep going. You gain momentum by doing. It’s not about when you start, it’s about how willing you are to learn. It’s about how committed you are to get the result you want. Read: What happens when you decide to change yourself? Just to be clear, I’m left handed, I play on a right handed guitar. So I play upside down (the big string is on the bottom). When I first started there were two kinds of people: Those that were impressed and continuously reminded me about Jimi Hendrix’s playing style.Those who actually got mad at me, and told me I’d never get anywhere playing that way because you can’t play a guitar upside-down!13 years later, here I am, more in love with making music than ever. In 2007 I got invited to join a metal band, which I played in for 2 years. I got invited to play guitar and bass in a church band. And in 2010 I switched to acoustic guitar which I’ve been doing ever since. I’ve written numerous songs, have an EP on iTunes, and have played live shows in coffee shops here and there. My point is, I might not have been “too old” to start, but the way I started was still unconventional. It “wasn’t supposed to happen.” It did because nobody could take away the love I had, the fun I had, when I make music. As long as there is a desire to make music, and a feeling of love and accomplishment when you make it, there’s nothing that can stop you. I went 2 years without a guitar. What did I do? Used my laptop to make music on my computer. Why? Because a lack of proper equipment didn’t cancel out my love for music. If I didn’t have a laptop, I’d probably tie rubber bands to a stick and learn how to make that sound good. I WANT to make music, and because of that, I’m going to, no matter what I need to do. “All you need is love. Love is all you need.” I love my guitar. I love my music. That’s all I need to continue playing my guitar and making music. :) If you love it, do it. Age is irrelevant.  (The rest of this is just me having a rant. Lol) The most common reason people give up on things they want to do, is because they don’t see results as quickly as they expected, or because they aren’t willing to put in the work required to get the results they’re after. 4 years ago I decided I wanted to create videogames. Guess how many I’ve made to this day? Zero. Why? Because even though I’ve watched COUNTLESS hours of Youtube tutorials in that 4 years, and have spent HUNDREDS of dollars on things to create videogames, every time I opened one of those programs, I realized it was a lot more work than I expected. More work than I wanted to put in to get the result. I just wanted the result. Everybody wants a button they can press to magically get the results they want. Whether with exercising, getting rich, getting good at something, getting popular, you name it. Some people call it “The magic bullet.” It doesn’t exist. You get good by doing, and doing again, and doing again. And while you’re doing you’re intentionally analyzing how to get better. I’ve been playing guitar for 13 years and I STILL miss strings and notes. So what do I do? I quickly analyze, “Why does my finger keep going to the wrong string?” Sometimes it’s something as small as “Oh, my fingernail is slightly too long and it’s throwing off my coordination somehow.” So I go cut my fingernails. Other times I realize that I picked up a bad muscle memory habit, so I keep playing the thing over and CONSCIOUSLY making sure I hit the right string. I’m reprogramming my brain to cooperate correctly with my fingers. Practice isn’t just doing the same thing over. It’s doing the same thing over and consciously adapting, adjusting and improving as you go. But you can’t do that if you don’t start going. You get better by looking at professionals (or people who have been doing it longer than you have) and learning how they think, how they create certain sounds, and what they see when they look at a guitar. Example: The other day I talked to my friend about guitar scales–something I’ve avoided forever because to me they are just a huge collection of notes I don’t know what to do with. As I was talking to him he casually said, “…I just look at the shapes of the scales and move those around the fret board.” I stopped him immediately. “Wait, wait, wait. So when you look at scales you don’t see all the individual notes? You see a shape comprised of all those notes?” “Yeah.” I IMMEDIATELY understand scales and was no longer intimidated by them, just by that simple change in perspective. All in all… It’s not too late. Nothing can stop you from starting anything, even when you’re 80 years old, besides you. Besides the idea that “It’s too late.” I’m 30 and single. My biggest fear, the thing that keeps me from asking girls out is this:,“It’s too late! I’m too old! All my other friends are already married and have kids! All I have is a cat!” Now imagine I keep that attitude up for another 10 years, guess what I’ll be? Single when I’m 40. The ONLY solution to that problem is to do what’s necessary to get the result I want. You want to be a musician? Do what’s necessary. Don’t know what’s necessary? First is committing to learn the instrument. Second is to get around (or at least talk to) people who are doing what you want to do, and you will naturally begin to pick things up from them. If you want to learn how to shoot a basketball, you wouldn’t ask a racecar driver.
